TopicTitle: Which is your favorite planetary body in the solar system?

Articles.Content:
Which is your favorite planetary body in the solar system?

Mine is Haumea. (Its a dwarf planet with two moons.)

Saturn

has Enceladus and Titan, two of the biggest candidates for life in my view
Jupiter hands down, it has Europa, one of the coolest moons ever, and it is huge.
What can i say, i love our good 'ol buddy The Moon
Gotta go with Saturn, too. It's just awesome...

Mars.

It is just too beautiful from space.

Big white ice caps in the poles, strong orange and earthy brown in the middle.

I still remember seeing it in Orbiter, it's drooling.

Earth.

Because on that planet, this odd thing called life exist on it.

Also because I live here.
Tied between Methone and Titan, I think... Runner up would be Jupiter. (can somebody explain to me why linebreaks aren't working on this forum?)

Mars.

Because that's going to be a place I call "home" in 2090.

My 1st would be Earth because both me, Nikola Tesla (My hero and idol), and many other Humans and animals wouldn't be living or have lived without it. My second choice, however, would be Jupiter's Callisto moon:

After Earth, Pluto. Poor guy had to be removed from planet status

For some reason the kerbal smiles don't work from the toolbar and I had to copy and paste the link to the image.
Nothing quite better than Earth.
Neptune has to be my favorite, simply for the deep blue color(blue is my favorite color).

I love Uranus. How could I not?

It's a rebel with its poles tilted almost 90 degrees from the rest of your silly conformist planets.
Imma say Europa. It just appeals to me.

Earth is by far my favorite. It has so much cool stuff on it.

Second is Triton, Neptune's largest moon. It's in a retrograde orbit that's almost perfectly circular. Next to that it has cryovolcanoes and geysers that keep the surface complex.

Besides Earth, probably Neptune, but since it has lost its lovely surface features, it's mostly a boring blue ball. I liked Neptune from the Voyager 2 era.

Triton is very cool, but some doubt there's actually liquid nitrogen spraying out.

By the way, did you know that Uranus took a lot more pounding than was previously thought?

http://www.dvice.com/archives/2011/10/we_now_know_why.php

Top Three:

1: Earth. Largest terrestrial planet in the Solar System with fascinating landscape and for 70% covered in oceans ... ! Noticed the gravity is a but harsh though when I fell down a mountain during skiing.

2: Mars. Interesting planet with interesting landscape and more or less within our reach.

3: Venus. Brutal and unforgiving hellhole. While not too far away, exploration is very difficult due to extreme conditions on the surface.

Gotta say I also find Titan interesting.
My favourite has to be Eris. Tiny planet drifts in, causes trouble, and Pluto gets demoted.
Mars because of its intriguing geologic history. I also love Europa for its potential biosphere and Titan for its crazy chemistry.
Either Eris or Sedna. I will cryogenically freeze myself for millennia if I have to to go to those...
Jupiter, its a monster compared to the Earth and makes me feel VERY very very small
I like Io, it's just so... weird!
I like Uranus (no joke please) as it is one of the most abnormal objects in our system.
Either Jupiter or Saturn ... must be a stunning view to stand on one of their moons and see them in their full beauty
